text: do you have a defined process for creating an option strategy do you even know where to start the goal of this video is to walk you through end to end and then to give you an example on what this can look like in a simple scenario but the punchline is if you're going to trade for hopefully a long time you have got to define a process for this while strategies are different and they vary based on circumstances the process to create one is not that different and we can define a well thought out process that we can multiply and apply in a bunch of different scenarios so that this isn't a painful thing that we're forgetting pieces because we're just kind of cobbling it together as we go what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to the outliers shout out to the patreon let's get right in so don't be this guy that's kind of the starting point so you can see we have a person here that they put on a trade and they're asking a Reddit Community should I hold on to expiration what's the problem here the trade's on like we are a day late dollar short you should already know what you're doing before you put the trade on don't be this guy this guy says I sold a put 5'11 expires today it's trading below but now it's above why didn't I get assigned so clearly they don't even understand

text: and so forth you can list out these different structures that work in this scenario this is going to help us later then we need to create a basic rule set So based on this idea of we want to trade something directionally to the upside what are the rules that we want to apply on entering the trade exiting the trade and then how long are we looking to hold these trades again if you trade options guess what you don't have the luxury of just picking a Direction all options have an expiration so not only do you need to pick a direction you also need to understand the severity how much it's going to move or have an idea on that and then you also need to have a Time bound component this is actually why options aren't always the right answer it adds a lot of complexity that may not need to be there but in any case these are kind of just three basic rules that you can start with to develop a strategy So based on this rule set I would then test those rules with a few things in mind the first one is I would start with a very big sample I would use the largest sample I could find so for example if I'm trying to trade something in the SPX that goes all the way back to the 20s I will literally run a test from the 20s until the

text: is I would start with a very big sample I would use the largest sample I could find so for example if I'm trying to trade something in the SPX that goes all the way back to the 20s I will literally run a test from the 20s until the nearest data I have does that mean I'm going to treade all that data the same no but that doesn't mean that I'm not going to acknowledge it because it's so far gone old data still is relevance so when I look at how do I then make this make more sense I segment the data so let's say I'm back testing 10-year period I'll run a 10-year back test then I'll run two five-year back tests then I'll do five 2year back tests then I'll do 10 one-ear back tests why do I do that because this helps me see the path of the strategy stry so for example you can have something like this in tle Q's where let's say you were just buying tle Qs and if you just test this broad data like Wow you went from 36 Cents to 59 that's a great return that's perfect meanwhile at one point you were all the way up at 92 and it fell all the way down to 16 that's the path of something so you might have something that has a crazy good return but then once you analyze it closer you might realize like okay

text: been three bare markets and two of those have been in the last four years what that means is if you just paper Trad this you're really getting a skewed view of the path something takes so I really believe in paper trading I do it with live strategies kind of actually in this sustained optimization stage as well but this stage page here step nine is when we're actually trading it exactly as we think we would and at the same time we have different variations that we're also paper trading so I kind of segment this into two buckets I have the paper trading I'm doing to simulate my actual account and then I have the paper trading I'm doing to collect data so the way I do that is the stuff I'm using to collect data I'll put on tons of different trades thousands of them and track them right I'm creating a data set I'm not worried about actually doing that exactly as I would but in the trading account that I'm testing as if it were live I'm going to size things exactly as I would I'm going to manage them exactly as I would because it gives me the best view of how this actually would work then we have our live test is when you start using real money none of this testing is ever going to be the same as using live Capital that's all there is to it but the idea

text: because it gives me the best view of how this actually would work then we have our live test is when you start using real money none of this testing is ever going to be the same as using live Capital that's all there is to it but the idea is we want to make as many mistakes as we can and get as much Headway as we can before we're throwing Capital at things I know for the impatient people I was in the beginning this seems really painful and a waste of time but the fact of the matter is is you are far more likely to lose money than make it as a Trader so by not losing money unnecessarily and setting your account back further than it needs to go you're actually moving faster in terms of compounding your Capital so going slow up front actually will get you a speedier result in the long run so what does this actually look like I kind of outlined what this in large steps goes down like and here's kind of a quick flow so in number one here I'm saying I need long beta weighted spy Deltas so that means I need something that goes up when the sp500 goes up this can be whatever you want this could be you need negative beta weighted spy Deltas so that you have some uncorrelated or non-correlated returns you could also say that I need non-correlated returns to the

text: so that means I need something that goes up when the sp500 goes up this can be whatever you want this could be you need negative beta weighted spy Deltas so that you have some uncorrelated or non-correlated returns you could also say that I need non-correlated returns to the SP 5 whatever it is whatever the use case is that you need for your portfolio in this stage here what I recommend to Traders is have a specific use case in mind don't just think about building strategies for the sake of it think about what the market does the market goes up I need a strategy for that things go down I need a strategy for that if I trade volatility I need a strategy to trade volatility when it goes up down sideways so as I look across the toolkit you can start to see that you don't need 35 different strategies you kind of just need a handful because you be need to be able to trade directionally up down you need to be able to trade volatility up down maybe there's a couple risk premum strategies in there momentum premum strategies in there news announcement strategies in there stuff like that but they're not all unique the way that I trade earnings is the very similar to the way that I trade fomc meetings I'm using the same structures just modifying them slightly so really think about how many strategies you need and what for

text: amount of money in both and you get the move in your favor you're going to make money with long options so you can also reason through some of this if you don't have access to the data when I start pairing down these different choices I think about the structures because is a long call the same thing as a short put no long calls have defined risk they have undefined profit potential so if the thesis that I'm trying to trade is directional momentum meaning I want it to move a lot would I prefer a long call or a short put probably the long call that's a better fit for that thesis a directional momentum trade if you trade a short put in that scenario it could still make money but you have a defined risk right at or defined profit right out of the gate and undefined risk so by understanding the qualities of the options you can then use that to further narrow down what best fits again what money-making mechanism you are trying to capitalize on then we go down to these last steps we're going to test multiple variations we're going to use something like this a strategy outline to document what we think we're going to do and then we iterate on this process a good example of this iteration and I'll throw a link in the notes below that talks about this exact thing where for zero DTE and even earnings
